page.title: 17The Shireoak.
page.content: It is generally accepted that the village of{Shireoaks}is named after a tree, or trees, near the village, which stood at the meeting place of three shires,{Derby,Notts}and{Yorks. The original tree, which was very large, having a spread of ninety four feet,survived until 1800 and may have been replaced by one until 1864. Another was not planted until 1951 but it unfortunately died and another was planted in{Jubilee Year,}1977, by the {Mothers Union.}This tree stands around 5m tall at present. Due to boundary changes the present tree does not stand on the original site, which was further to the east than it is today. It is not thought that the{Shireoak was ever used for any traditional events, such as the{Mayday Morris {Dancing}at the{Todwick Trysting Tree, but has been an unusual boundary mark.
